title: Polynesia
summary: Polynesia (UK: /ˌpɒlɪˈniːziə/, US: /-ˈniːʒə/; from Ancient Greek: πολύς polys "many" and Ancient Greek: νῆσος nēsos "island") (Tongan: Faka-Polinisia; Māori: Porinihia; Hawaiian: Polenekia; Fijian: Kai-Polinesia; Samoan: Polenisia; Cook Islands Māori: Porinetia; Tahitian: Pōrīnetia; Tuvaluan: Polenisia; Tokelauan: Polenihia) is a subregion of Oceania, made up of more than 1,000 islands scattered over the central and southern Pacific Ocean. The indigenous people who inhabit the islands of Polynesia are called Polynesians. They have many things in common, including language relatedness, cultural practices, and traditional beliefs.[1] In centuries past, they had a strong shared tradition of sailing and using stars to navigate at night.[2][3] The largest country in Polynesia is New Zealand.
